content.description: Yellow Jacket is found about in the middle of the cliff and is the quite obvious smooth face starting about 15' off the ground.  The three bolts are easily visible. It is not the larger smooth face seen further left which has 3 routes (5.8,9, and 10) which are toprope only.  Clipping the first bolt requires care and getting to and clipping the third bolt is definitely the crux.  A very fun route!
content.protection: Three bolts to 2 bolt anchor adequately protects this route although clipping the first bolt requires a 5.6 move or so and you are up about 15-20' off the ground.

content.description:
Like a (very) poor man's

On the Lamb

, this dirty, gently rising crack traverse is pretty fun although brief in length. A bit of featured slab gains entry to the left side start where protection is easily had. Midway the protection thins out for a few moves until you get a couple of solid pieces. The end of this horizontal crack leads into the finish of the Undercling Thing's real climbing. All in all, probably 25' of business followed by an anchor scramble.

From there, either head up or climber's right and around to access the anchors.

I'm calling this The Unknown Phantom because this climb is not featured in any of the guidebooks I have available for the area (both old and new Carville guides, and the new North Tahoe book). If you know the FA information, let me know so I can change the description, I am sure it has been led or free soloed before. This climb is definitely a fun, albeit overlooked diversion while in the area and a few more parties on it might clean up the mossy placements!
content.protection: Small to 3" cams. There is a bonus #1 camalot placement in a downward facing pocket as well. Pro appears solid, although the rock is a bit grainy and mossy inside the crack. Bolted anchors shared with Undercling Thing.
content.location: The crack that gently diagonals up and right, 25' left from the start of the Undercling Thing.

content.description: Very nice challenging face climb next to Fine Line Crack 5.9+. The bottom has pretty good hands and feet but it gets thin quick. There's a hollow flake a little more than half way that's tempting for the right hand but will probably break off soon. If anyone knows the FA and name let me know!
content.protection: Two bolts with hangers up top that are shared with Fine Line.

content.description: A meandering low angle crimp fest
content.protection: TR off of shared anchor for Rib Line and Fine Line
content.location: Start on a small boulder. Between Rib Line and Fine Line

content.description: The start is the crux, then after that the climbing eases substantially.
content.protection: Trad gear.
content.location: Left of "Fine Line." The left trending diagnonal flake.

content.description: Roccocater is found just up and right from Yellow Jacket, and follows a face which is found after scrambling up about 20' to a nice large ledge.  A thin step left after clipping the first bolt finds you at the base of some thin, steeper face climbing.  Climbing past the second bolt and clipping the third is the crux.  The climb then eases to the top.  A very fun climb but just don't hang out too long and keep cool clipping that third bolt!
content.protection: 4 bolts to 2 bolt anchors.  It seems all the bolts are a bit to the right of the actual climbing (except getting to first bolt) possibly to keep a falling leader from hitting the corner to the left.

content.description: Near vertical edging up the left end of the water streaked wall. Short slabby traverse right after the second bolt to finish out at the bolted anchor.
content.protection: Two old metolius bolts, Two bolt anchor.
content.location: start just left of the small roof.

content.description: A nice cruise up a well-featured mini-buttress. Start at the toe of the face on the left of the formation. gaining a small sloping ledge a few feet off the ground. Continue up and slightly right, following intermittent, flaring cracks to a steep step (crux). Friction and tension are your friends here; a few more moves and the angle eases. Finish at the anchors shared with "Fine Line."
content.protection: Cams from .5" to 1.5. Tricky, if any, nut placements. Tricams could possibly work. Owing to potential for tricky gear placements, experience at the grade is probably best for a the leader.
content.location: The route starts 25' to the left of "Fine Line" on a blunt areté.  Begin where a shallow, fractured, flaring crack system ascends up and and slightly right.

content.description:
I would typify this climb as "trad bouldering" (trouldering?). Although brief in length, awkward, technically demanding climbing combines with burliness in order to make a difficult lead indeed.

Face climb to first bolt, then face/crack climb up a left angling crack using whatever technique works. At the jug capped apex of the crack head slightly right and up using small but solid protection in seams for the last sporty feeling move to gain the ill-placed anchors.

Despite the flared nature of the crack, there are enough pods for gear to make the lead not as serious as it could be.
content.protection: 1 1/4" bolt, pro from fingers to 1", two anchor bolts
content.location:
Technically, not at Green Phantom, but closer to it than any other formation. From Green Phantom Slabs head up the gully to the North. Halfway up, the boulder with Power Struggle on it will be encountered, right of the faint trail/wash coming down the gully.

Alternately, Power Struggle may be approached from above on the PCT by going just past the telephone lines and leaving the trail to go down the gully where the PCT angles East toward Grouse Slabs.

content.description:
The thinnest of the three routes, but not the most sustained.

Sort of a rules/eliminate problem.
content.protection: TR
content.location: Just right of Staircase Middle.  Crux involves a small divot iirc...

content.description: Phantom Staircase Middle is a very continuous thin face climb that goes up the middle of the face.  Staying clear and just left of the obvious wide crack start adds 15' of additional fun face climbing.  Small holds are found all the way up with maybe a crux section just shy of the anchors.
content.protection: This route can be toproped only from the two bolt anchors.  Longer slings are needed to clear the edge.
content.location: See Phantom Staircase Left for info.

content.description: This climb is a very continuous face climb from bottom to top if you stay clear of the arete on the left side.  Good footwork and balance are required which makes this a very good practice climb.
content.protection: This route can only be toproped.
content.location: After going under the old bridge, veer to the right about 30' to the top of an obvious flat topped rock with a small tree near the edge.  Two bolts left of the tree can be used to protect the Phantom Staircase face.  Longer slings are needed to clear the edge making it for a difficult rappel.  Really make an effort to stack coils of rope and throw the rope out clear of the rock to reach the bottom otherwise you may find the rope hung up on ledges out of reach when you walk down.  Although there is a class 5 descent about 30' right (facing rock), an easy walk down can be found 100' right (facing rock).

content.description:
Opera House is a very technical climb compared to other slab climbs in the area. The moves are relatively easy to figure out but doing the moves may not be as easy. The second half of the climb is on a much lower angle slab and in my opinion, is much easier. The two cruxes are the first two moves of the climb and getting over the edge onto the second half of the slab. Opera House shares anchors with

Phantom Crack far left

, and falling near the beginning might make for a nice swing.
content.protection: Two anchors at the top.
content.location:
The route starts next to or on a small outcrop of rock around the corner of

Phantom Crack far left

.

climbs.name: No Word, No Message, No Letter

content.description:
If someone has better info on the FA and the actual name of this climb please post and I will update the description.

Down and to the left of the Phantom Staircase climbs there is a lichen covered slab with a left slanting crack.

Climb this left slanting crack to the top of the slab, you can stop here and clip the super old anchors (which are overdue to be replaced in my opinion), or you can look to your right and continue up the obvious stemming slot to the top of the Phantom Staircase climbs. There is a single bolt at the top of this crack which can be backed up by the tree and makes for a good anchor to be lowered back done. Make sure you have a 60m rope because a 50m won't make it back down.

This is probably the easiest climb in the area, but since there is limited info in the book it rarely gets done. It is a good climb for someone looking for their first gear lead, or for a beginner to second it and clean. It could also be TRed if you choose to use the old bolts on top for anchors, not recommended though.
content.protection: mostly finger sized pieces for pro. One bolt backed up by the tree at the top of the Phantom Staircase climbs to lower off of after leading.
content.location: Located on the slab to the left of the Phantom Staircase. In the Lake Tahoe climbing guidebook this slab has some top rope anchors and is marked as Unknown.

content.description:
Climb the slab to the right of Undercling Thing. Some fun balancy moves gets you onto steeper terrain. Then face climb up ledges to a crack finish, it was pumpier than I though it was going to be. Definatly more physical than the surrounding climbs.

Really good climbing, although short. The crux for me was getting from the legdes up to the crack.
content.protection:
TR off trees or boulders up top.

Or lead using traditional gear. Not much gear to be had until after the crux, just before the top out. You could probably fiddle in a small alein to protect the crux move, but I wouldn't want to fall on it.
content.location: Located to the right of the obvious flake in the center of the area called Undercling Thing.

content.description: the wide crack to the left of phantom staircase slab. the Crux is the wide squeeze part of the crack up to a ledge at 50ish feet. once on the ledge step right and climb up the 5.5ish dihedral to the top. Two bolt anchor (one older, one newer).
content.protection: up to 4"
content.location: the next wide crack to the right of no word, no message, no letter

content.description: a super easy hand to fist staircase like crack running up the right side of the phantom staircase slab.  belay from the ledge up and to the right from the bottom of the phantom staircase TR routes
content.protection: up to 5"
content.location: obvious hand to fist crack on the far right side of phantom staircase slab

content.description: Fun thin fingers and edging
content.protection: gear to 1", no bolts for anchor
content.location: right side of the wall where Chlorite is.

content.description: Very short crack climb with the crux being getting to the crack that starts 10 feet up. I felt the route was more about 5.8
content.protection: 2 bolt TR anchor up top

content.description: A short but fun, left-leaning crack and ramp. Crux after the first ten feet. Luxurious hand jams and good face-holds. Abundant, straight-forward placements for gear. With adequate crack technique, this would make an excellent first traditional lead.
content.protection: Single rack from 1" to 3.5"
content.location: This route follows the crack/ramp immediately right of "Roccocater." Shares anchor with "Roccocater." Walk-off.
